entities.title: Rory O'Donnell, 1st Earl of Tyrconnell
entities.description: Rory O'Donnell was the last King of Tyrconnell and 1st Earl of Tyrconnell.

entities.title: Tyrconnell
entities.description: Tyrconnell, also spelled Tirconnell, was a kingdom of Gaelic Ireland, associated geographically with present-day County Donegal in Ulster, which has sometimes been called County Tyrconnell. At times it also included parts of County Fermanagh, County Sligo, County Leitrim, County Tyrone and County Londonderry at its greatest extent. The kingdom represented the core homeland of the Cenél Conaill peo

heading: Deaths
txt: Esmé Stewart, 3rd Duke of Lennox, British nobleman (b. 1579)

entities.title: Esmé Stewart, 3rd Duke of Lennox
entities.description: Esmé Stewart, 3rd Duke of Lennox, KG, lord of the Manor of Cobham, Kent, was a Scottish nobleman and through their paternal lines was a second cousin of King James VI of Scotland and I of England. He was a patron of the playwright Ben Jonson who lived in his household for five years.

heading: Deaths
txt: Charles Amadeus, Duke of Nemours (b. 1624)

entities.title: Charles Amadeus, Duke of Nemours
entities.description: Charles Amadeus of Savoy, Duke of Nemours was a French military leader and magnate. He was the father of the penultimate Duchess of Savoy and of a Queen of Portugal.

heading: Deaths
txt: Thomas Butler, 6th Earl of Ossory, Irish admiral and politician, Lord Lieutenant of Ireland (b. 1634)

entities.title: Thomas Butler, 6th Earl of Ossory
entities.description: Vice-Admiral Thomas Butler, 6th Earl of Ossory, KG, PC, PC (Ire) (1634–1680) was an Irish soldier and politician. He was born at Kilkenny Castle, the eldest son of James Butler, 1st Duke of Ormond, and his wife Elizabeth Preston.

entities.title: Lord Lieutenant of Ireland
entities.description: Lord Lieutenant of Ireland, or more formally Lord Lieutenant General and General Governor of Ireland, was the title of the chief governor of Ireland from the Williamite Wars of 1690 until the Partition of Ireland in 1922. This spanned the Kingdom of Ireland (1541–1800) and the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland (1801–1922). The office, under its various names, was often more generally kno

heading: Deaths
txt: Maria Theresa of Spain (b. 1638)

entities.title: Maria Theresa of Spain
entities.description: Maria Theresa of Spain, was by birth Infanta of Spain and Portugal and Archduchess of Austria as member of the Spanish branch of the House of Habsburg and by marriage Queen of France.

heading: Deaths
txt: Daniel Georg Morhof, German scholar and academic (b. 1639)

entities.title: Daniel Georg Morhof
entities.description: Daniel Georg Morhof was a German writer and scholar.

heading: Deaths
txt: Prince William, Duke of Gloucester, English royal (b. 1689)

entities.title: Prince William, Duke of Gloucester
entities.description: Prince William, Duke of Gloucester, was the son of Princess Anne and her husband, Prince George of Denmark. He was their only child to survive infancy. Styled Duke of Gloucester, he was viewed by contemporaries as a Protestant champion because his birth seemed to cement the Protestant succession established in the "Glorious Revolution" that had deposed his Catholic grandfather James II the previou

heading: Deaths
txt: William Penn, English businessman and philosopher, founded the Province of Pennsylvania (b. 1644)

entities.title: William Penn
entities.description: William Penn was an English writer and religious thinker belonging to the Religious Society of Friends (Quakers), and founder of the Province of Pennsylvania, a North American colony of England. He was an early advocate of democracy and religious freedom, notable for his good relations and successful treaties with the Lenape Native Americans. Under his direction, the city of Philadelphia was plann

entities.title: Province of Pennsylvania
entities.description: The Province of Pennsylvania, also known as the Pennsylvania Colony, was a British North American colony founded by William Penn after receiving a land grant from Charles II of England in 1681. The name Pennsylvania refers to William's father, Admiral Sir William Penn.

heading: Deaths
txt: Thomas Gray, English poet (b. 1716)

entities.title: Thomas Gray
entities.description: Thomas Gray was an English poet, letter-writer, classical scholar, and professor at Pembroke College, Cambridge. He is widely known for his Elegy Written in a Country Churchyard, published in 1751.

heading: Deaths
txt: Miguel Hidalgo y Costilla, Mexican priest and soldier (b. 1753)

entities.title: Miguel Hidalgo y Costilla
entities.description: Don Miguel Gregorio Antonio Francisco Ignacio Hidalgo-Costilla y Gallaga Mandarte Villaseñor, more commonly known as Don Miguel Hidalgo y Costilla or Miguel Hidalgo, was a Spanish Catholic priest, a leader of the Mexican War of Independence, and recognized as the Father of the Nation.

heading: Deaths
txt: Lê Văn Duyệt, Vietnamese general, mandarin (b. 1763-4)

entities.title: Lê Văn Duyệt
entities.description: Lê Văn Duyệt was a Vietnamese general who helped Nguyễn Ánh—the future Emperor Gia Long—put down the Tây Sơn rebellion, unify Vietnam and establish the Nguyễn Dynasty. After the Nguyễn came to power in 1802, Duyệt became a high-ranking mandarin, serving under the first two Nguyễn emperors Gia Long and Minh Mạng.

heading: Deaths
txt: Aasmund Olavsson Vinje, Norwegian poet and journalist (b. 1818)

entities.title: Aasmund Olavsson Vinje
entities.description: Aasmund Olavsson Vinje was a Norwegian poet and journalist who is remembered for poetry, travel writing, and his pioneering use of Landsmål.

heading: Deaths
txt: George Pickett, American general (b. 1825)

entities.title: George Pickett
entities.description: George Edward Pickett was a career United States Army officer who became a major general in the Confederate States Army during the American Civil War. He is best remembered for being one of the commanders at Pickett's Charge, the futile and bloody Confederate offensive on the third day of the Battle of Gettysburg that bears his name.

heading: Deaths
txt: Charlie Absolom, England cricketer (b. 1846)

entities.title: Charlie Absolom
entities.description: Charles Alfred Absolom was an English amateur cricketer who played for Cambridge University, Kent County Cricket Club and England in the period from 1866 to 1879.

heading: Deaths
txt: Otto von Bismarck, German lawyer and politician, 1st Chancellor of Germany (b. 1815)

entities.title: Otto von Bismarck
entities.description: Otto Eduard Leopold, Prince of Bismarck, Duke of Lauenburg, known as Otto von Bismarck, was a conservative German statesman who masterminded the unification of Germany in 1871 and served as its first chancellor until 1890, in which capacity he dominated European affairs for two decades. He had previously been Minister President of Prussia (1862–1890) and Chancellor of the North German Confederatio

entities.title: Chancellor of Germany
entities.description: The chancellor of Germany, officially the federal chancellor of the Federal Republic of Germany, is the head of government and chief executive of Germany, as well as the commander in chief of the German Armed Forces during wartime. The chancellor is elected by the Bundestag on the proposal of the federal president and without debate.

heading: Deaths
txt: Alfred, Duke of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha (b. 1844)

entities.title: Alfred, Duke of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha
entities.description: Alfred reigned as Duke of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha from 1893 to 1900. He was the second son and fourth child of Queen Victoria of the United Kingdom and Albert, Prince Consort. He was known as the Duke of Edinburgh from 1866 until he succeeded his paternal uncle Ernest II as the reigning Duke of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha in the German Empire.

heading: Deaths
txt: Emperor Meiji of Japan (b. 1852)

entities.title: Emperor Meiji
entities.description: Emperor Meiji , also called Meiji the Great , or Meiji the Good , was the 122nd Emperor of Japan according to the traditional order of succession, reigning from 3 February 1867 until his death on 30 July 1912, and the first monarch of the Empire of Japan. He presided over the Meiji era, a time of rapid change that witnessed Japan's transformation from an isolationist, feudal state to an industrial

heading: Deaths
txt: Joyce Kilmer, American soldier, journalist, and poet (b. 1886)

entities.title: Joyce Kilmer
entities.description: Alfred Joyce Kilmer was an American writer and poet mainly remembered for a short poem titled "Trees" (1913), which was published in the collection Trees and Other Poems in 1914. Though a prolific poet whose works celebrated the common beauty of the natural world as well as his Roman Catholic religious faith, Kilmer was also a journalist, literary critic, lecturer, and editor. At the time of his d

heading: Deaths
txt: Albert Gustaf Dahlman, Swedish executioner (b. 1848)

entities.title: Albert Gustaf Dahlman
entities.description: Albert Gustaf Dalman, was a Swedish executioner. He was the last executioner in Sweden, as well as the last to carry out capital punishment in Sweden, of Alfred Ander in 1910, the last by means of beheading by hand and the last to execute a woman.

heading: Deaths
txt: Joan Gamper, Swiss-Spanish footballer and businessman, founded FC Barcelona (b. 1877)

entities.title: Joan Gamper
entities.description: Hans Max Gamper-Haessig, known in Catalonia as Joan Gamper, was a Swiss football pioneer, versatile athlete and club president. He founded football clubs in Switzerland and Spain, most notably FC Barcelona and FC Zürich.

entities.title: FC Barcelona
entities.description: Futbol Club Barcelona, commonly referred to as Barcelona and colloquially known as Barça, is a Spanish professional football club based in Barcelona, that competes in La Liga, the top flight of Spanish football.

heading: Deaths
txt: John Derbyshire, English swimmer and water polo player (b. 1878)

entities.title: John Derbyshire (swimmer)
entities.description: John Henry "Rob" Derbyshire was an English freestyle swimmer and water polo player from Chorlton, Lancashire, who competed in the 1900 Summer Olympics, 1906 Intercalated Games, 1908 Summer Olympics and 1912 Summer Olympics.

heading: Deaths
txt: Hugo Celmiņš, Latvian politician, former Prime Minister of Latvia (b. 1877)

entities.title: Hugo Celmiņš
entities.description: Hugo Celmiņš was a Latvian politician, a public employee, agronomist, twice the Prime Minister of Latvia. Arrested and deported to the USSR after the occupation of Latvia, imprisoned in Moscow's Lefortovo Prison. On 30 July 1941 shot and buried in the mass graves of Kommunarka shooting ground. Hugo Celmiņš was one of those who developed agrarian reform in Latvia.

entities.title: Prime Minister of Latvia
entities.description: The prime minister of Latvia is the most powerful member of the Government of Latvia, and presides over the Latvian Cabinet of Ministers. The prime minister is nominated by the president of Latvia, but must be able to obtain the support of a majority of the Saeima (parliament).

heading: Deaths
txt: Joseph Cook, English-Australian miner and politician, 6th Prime Minister of Australia (b. 1860)

entities.title: Joseph Cook
entities.description: Sir Joseph Cook, was an Australian politician who served as the sixth Prime Minister of Australia, in office from 1913 to 1914. He was the leader of the Commonwealth Liberal Party from 1913 to 1917, after earlier serving as the leader of the Anti-Socialist Party from 1908 to 1909.

entities.title: Prime Minister of Australia
entities.description: The prime minister of Australia is the head of government of Australia. The prime minister is the leader of the federal government and is also accountable to federal parliament under the principles of responsible government. The incumbent prime minister is Scott Morrison, who took office in August 2018 as leader of the Liberal Party.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jun'ichirō Tanizaki, Japanese author and playwright (b. 1886)

entities.title: Jun'ichirō Tanizaki
entities.description: Jun'ichirō Tanizaki  was a Japanese author who is considered to be one of the most prominent figures in modern Japanese literature. The tone and subject matter of his work ranges from shocking depictions of sexuality and destructive erotic obsessions to subtle portrayals of the dynamics of family life within the context of the rapid changes in 20th-century Japanese society. Frequently, his stories

heading: Deaths
txt: Walter Murdoch, Scottish-Australian academic (b. 1874)

entities.title: Walter Murdoch
entities.description: Sir Walter Logie Forbes Murdoch, was a prominent Australian academic and essayist famous for his intelligence and wit. He was a founding professor of English and former Chancellor of the University of Western Australia (UWA) in Perth, Western Australia.

heading: Deaths
txt: George Szell, Hungarian-American conductor and composer (b. 1897)

heading: Deaths
txt: Thomas Hollway, Australian politician, 36th Premier of Victoria (b. 1906)

entities.title: Thomas Hollway
entities.description: Thomas Tuke Hollway was the 36th Premier of Victoria, and the first to be born in the 20th century. He held office from 1947 to 1950, and again for a short period in 1952. He was originally a member and the leader of the United Australia Party (UAP) in Victoria, and was the inaugural leader of the UAP's successor, the Victorian division of the Liberal Party, but split from the Liberals after a dis

entities.title: Premier of Victoria
entities.description: The Premier of Victoria is the head of government in the Australian state of Victoria. The Premier is appointed by the governor of Victoria, and is the leader of the political party able to secure a majority in the Victorian Legislative Assembly.

heading: Deaths
txt: James Blish, American author and critic (b. 1921)

entities.title: James Blish
entities.description: James Benjamin Blish was an American science fiction and fantasy writer. He is best known for his Cities in Flight novels, and his series of Star Trek novelizations written with his wife, J. A. Lawrence. He is credited with creating the term "gas giant" to refer to large planetary bodies.

heading: Deaths
txt: Emory Holloway, American scholar, author, and educator (b. 1885)

entities.title: Emory Holloway
entities.description: Rufus Emory Holloway is an American literary scholar-educator most known for his books and studies of Walt Whitman. His Whitman: An Interpretation in Narrative (1926) was the first biography of a literary figure to win the Pulitzer Prize for Biography or Autobiography in 1927.

heading: Deaths
txt: Howard Dietz, American songwriter and publicist (b. 1896)

entities.title: Howard Dietz
entities.description: Howard Dietz was an American publicist, lyricist, and librettist, best remembered for his songwriting collaboration with Arthur Schwartz.

heading: Deaths
txt: Lynn Fontanne, English actress (b. 1887)

heading: Deaths
txt: Julia Robinson, American mathematician and theorist (b. 1919)

entities.title: Julia Robinson
entities.description: Julia Hall Bowman Robinson was an American mathematician noted for her contributions to the fields of computability theory and computational complexity theory—most notably in decision problems. Her work on Hilbert's tenth problem played a crucial role in its ultimate resolution. Robinson was a 1983 MacArthur Fellow.

heading: Deaths
txt: Lane Frost, American professional bull rider (b. 1963)

entities.title: Lane Frost
entities.description: Lane Clyde Frost was an American professional rodeo cowboy who specialized in bull riding, and competed in the Professional Rodeo Cowboys Association (PRCA). He was the 1987 PRCA World Champion bull rider and a 1990 ProRodeo Hall of Fame inductee. heading: Deaths
txt: Ian Gow, British Member of Parliament who was assassinated by the IRA (b. 1937)

entities.title: Ian Gow
entities.description: Ian Reginald Edward Gow was a British Conservative politician and solicitor. While serving as Member of Parliament (MP) for Eastbourne, he was assassinated by the Provisional Irish Republican Army (IRA), who exploded a bomb under his car outside his home in East Sussex.

heading: Deaths
txt: Brenda Marshall, Filipino-American actress and singer (b. 1915)

entities.title: Brenda Marshall
entities.description: Ardis Ankerson, known as Brenda Marshall, was an American film actress.

heading: Deaths
txt: Joe Shuster, Canadian-American illustrator, co-created Superman (b. 1914)

entities.title: Superman
entities.description: Superman is a fictional superhero who first appeared in American comic books published by DC Comics. The character was created by writer Jerry Siegel and artist Joe Shuster, and first appeared in the comic book Action Comics #1. Superman has been adapted to a number of other media which includes radio serials, novels, movies, television shows and theatre.

heading: Deaths
txt: Claudette Colbert, French-American actress (b. 1903)

entities.title: Claudette Colbert
entities.description: Claudette Colbert was an American actress.

heading: Deaths
txt: Bảo Đại, Vietnamese emperor (b. 1913)

entities.title: Bảo Đại
entities.description: Bảo Đại, born Nguyễn Phúc Vĩnh Thụy, was the 13th and final Emperor of the Nguyễn dynasty, the last ruling family of Vietnam. From 1926 to 1945, he was Emperor of Annam, which was then a protectorate in French Indochina, covering the central two thirds of the present-day Vietnam. Bảo Đại ascended the throne in 1932.

heading: Deaths
txt: Buffalo Bob Smith, American television host (b. 1917)

entities.title: Buffalo Bob Smith
entities.description: Buffalo Bob Smith was the host of the children's show Howdy Doody.

heading: Deaths
txt: Anton Schwarzkopf, German engineer (b. 1924)

entities.title: Anton Schwarzkopf
entities.description: Anton Schwarzkopf was a German engineer of amusement rides, and founder of the Schwarzkopf Industries Company, which built numerous amusement rides and large roller coasters for both amusement parks and traveling funfairs.

entities.description: Robert Steven 'Hizzy' Hislop was a Scottish motorcycle racer. Hislop won at the Isle of Man TT eleven times, won the British 250cc Championship (1990) and British Superbike championship.

entities.title: Sun Records
entities.description: Sun Records is an American independent record label founded by producer Sam Phillips in Memphis, Tennessee in February 1952. Sun was the first label to record Elvis Presley, Charlie Rich, Roy Orbison, Jerry Lee Lewis, Carl Perkins, and Johnny Cash. heading: Deaths
txt: Ray Cunningham, American baseball player (b. 1905)

entities.title: Ray Cunningham
entities.description: Raymond Lee "Ray" Cunningham was an American third baseman in Major League Baseball who played for the St. Louis Cardinals in 1931 and 1932. He batted and threw right-handed. A native of Mesquite, Texas, Cunningham played briefly for the Cardinals at third base before an injury cut short his career. He injured himself, whipping a sidearm throw to first base on a swinging bunt.

txt: Anne Armstrong, American businesswoman and diplomat, United States Ambassador to the United Kingdom (b. 1927)

entities.title: Anne Armstrong
entities.description: Anne Legendre Armstrong was a United States diplomat and politician. She was the first woman to serve as Counselor to the President and as United States Ambassador to the United Kingdom, serving in those capacities under the Ford, Nixon, and Carter administrations. She was the recipient of the Presidential Medal of Freedom in 1987.

entities.title: United States Ambassador to the United Kingdom
entities.description: The United States ambassador to the United Kingdom is the official representative of the president of the United States and the government of the United States of America to the Queen and Government of the United Kingdom.

txt: Mohammed Yusuf, Nigerian militant leader, founded Boko Haram (b. 1970)

entities.title: Mohammed Yusuf (Boko Haram)
entities.description: Mohammed Yusuf, also known as Ustaz Mohammed Yusuf, was a Nigerian terrorist and founder of the militant Islamist group Boko Haram in 2002. He was its spiritual leader until he was killed in the 2009 Boko Haram uprising The group's official name is Jama'atu Ahlis Sunna Lidda'awati wal-Jihad, which in Arabic means "People Committed to the Propagation of the Prophet's Teachings and Jihad".

entities.title: Boko Haram
entities.description: Boko Haram, officially known as Jamā'at Ahl as-Sunnah lid-Da'wah wa'l-Jihād, and Wilāyat Garb Ifrīqīyā, meaning "West African Province", is a jihadist terrorist organization based in northeastern Nigeria, which is also active in Chad, Niger and northern Cameroon.

entities.title: Cecil Alexander (architect)
entities.description: Cecil Abraham Alexander, Jr. was an American architect, principally a designer of commercial architecture, best known for his work in Atlanta, Georgia. He worked with the firm FABRAP, which, in 1985, became Rosser FABRAP International and later Rosser International. Together with other architects of the firm, he "shaped the skyline of Atlanta".

entities.title: State of Georgia Building
entities.description: The State of Georgia Building, alternately referenced as 2 Peachtree Street, is a 44-story, 566 feet (173 m) skyscraper located in downtown Atlanta, Georgia, U.S.. Built in 1966, the building was the tallest building in the Southeast at the time. It was Atlanta's tallest until 1976, when the Westin Peachtree Plaza surpassed it. entities.description: Robert Lincoln Drew was an American documentary filmmaker known as one of the pioneers—and sometimes called father—of cinéma vérité, or direct cinema, in the United States. The moving image collection of Robert Drew is housed at the Academy Film Archive.

He was the first president to be born in Taiwan, the last to be indirectly elected and the first to be directly elected. entities.title: Mayor of Taipei
entities.description: The Mayor of Taipei is the head of the Taipei City Government and is elected to a four-year term. Until the election of Tsai Ing-wen, the office was seen as a stepping stone to the presidency: presidents Lee Teng-hui, Chen Shui-bian and Ma Ying-jeou have all held this position prior to being elected president.
